message: Geocities used to give average people the ability to make websites for free.  Sure, it ended up being poorly maintained and often ugly, but it that was a long time ago.
true
http://about.me/ & http://flavors.me/ may be somewhat in that direction.
He could make it a blog post on tumblr or image on flickr.
I'm not a fan, but did you try WordPress pages?
I'd say try to find a niche that would use this. And make it as easy as possible for them to.
ok, that's what we were thinking
I've seen some people use http://www.squarespace.com
Of course, but they aren't made for that.

You can't fit every website into the blog format.  I've been focussing a lot on projects recently; like, a research project would have a website with a few unique pages.  But a blog just stresses the most current news, which often isn't that important for stuff that's been done completely.

I'm wondering if there are any similar websites that are popular right now.  I know there are general website-template making sites, but most don't seem as easy.  There are blogs, but not all websites are blogs.
I think we do, but it'll need to be simpler and beautiful to wean people off facebook.
Good point.  We were considering doing so, as soon as a few well done implementations were made.
I've thought about those two, but they are still splash pages,  My science teacher can't show an experiment up there.
no, I never experimented much with wordpress
pretty much, from what I read on Wikipedia
aiming it specifically at hardware hackers, because they really need a project database
At some point, highlight really well done implementations like flavors.me so people can quickly see the potential.

I was asking the question because I've been creating a website but we've had some trouble figuring out what direction to really take it in first.  We just knew it seemed pretty useful.  Then recently I thought more about Geocities, looked it up, and was impressed.  It's always talked down upon now but the idea was pretty useful.
I know it's easy, but I've always thought of it as a more complex platform, somewhere between coding the website and a simple blog
I'll check it out
$12 per month?  It does look nice though
We're still working on it, but here is what I was working on to create pages specifically for projects
http://holono.com/projects/1
just trying to think how we should focus on it, if we should develop it torwards being a geocities
And apple has iweb.
I'm not sure, but I'm guessing geocities failed because it wasn't profitable being ad supported?
From what I remember hearing, it was also a pretty ugly website.  Users made pages kind of similar to Myspace
Yahoo bought it and made a lot of users angry
What about Google Sites?
Yahoo does that.
Any decent free ones?
I'm trying it now.  The templates are surprisingly ugly, but the website is definitely free.  Editing is easy.
virb, squarespace, all those .me sites
@ZoFreX You're right, I haven't checked out Google Sites.   Honestly I didn't know it existed.
I've been using it to keep notes on bits and bobs, it's ok... not great but ok. The bolt-on functionality for more dynamic sites looks interesting.
agreed with the earlier comment... now we have wordpress and tumblr. and honestly, i think wordpress.com is the new geocities... free option available, your own design, pages and blogs / news...
Used to work at Webs.com
bonus: http://wonder-tonic.com/geocitiesizer/
basically geocities 2.0
yes! collages are what we need.
@ogooen  yeh but what features do you "think" geocities had that isnt already available on wordpress.com ?
wordpress.com is simple enough.
theres also quite a few "hosting" places that provide free service if you are small like heroku and amazon web services, though they lack the wysiwyg website creation of geocities

Surprised this hasn't been mentioned, but Squidoo.com strikes me as the obvious choice here. I've made a ton of pages on Squidoo that it wouldn't really be feasible for me to have created in any other medium.
http://weebly.com
